notes: Steinwender (2018), 'Real Effects of Information Frictions: When the States and the Kingdom became United'. Exploits the transatlantic telegraph (1866) as a natural experiment. Daily time-series data on cotton prices in New York and Liverpool. Main analysis uses before/after comparison with Newey-West SE. Key tables: Table 2 (effect on price differences and variance), Table 8 (effect on trade levels), Table 9 (effect on trade variance). Also includes IV specifications (Table 3, information lag instrumented by telegraph), ARIMA price transmission (Tables 4-5), and structural demand/supply estimation (Tables 11-12). The design is primarily a before-after comparison (DiD in the simplest sense: pre vs post telegraph).

design_audit.notes: Daily time-series regressions. Newey-West SE with 2 lags. Treatment: tele = 1 after telegraph introduction (1866). Outcome: cotton price difference between Liverpool and NY. tsset day (or ct_t, ct_notrade for different sample constructions). Before-after comparison, not a panel DiD.

claim_object.outcome_concept: Cotton price difference between Liverpool and New York (pence/pound), adjusted for freight cost
claim_object.treatment_concept: Introduction of the transatlantic telegraph (1866), tele = 1 for post-telegraph period
claim_object.estimand_concept: Effect of telegraph on the average level and variance of the transatlantic cotton price gap, capturing reduced information frictions
claim_object.target_population: Daily cotton trade between Liverpool and New York, ~1860-1868

baseline_specs.label: Table2-Col1
baseline_specs.notes: newey diff tele, lag(2). Price difference regressed on telegraph dummy. Simplest specification.

baseline_specs.label: Table2-Col2
baseline_specs.notes: newey difffrctotal tele l1nyrec, lag(2). Price diff net of freight cost, controlling for lagged NY receipts. Sample excludes no-trade days (ct_notrade).

baseline_specs.label: Table2-Col3
baseline_specs.notes: Forward-looking price difference (using future Liverpool price known at time of NY sale) net of freight.

constraints.notes: Very limited control pool. The paper uses l1nyrec (lagged NY cotton receipts) as the main control. Freight cost adjustment is done by redefining the outcome, not as a control. The time-series structure means few cross-sectional controls are available.

canonical.notes: Newey-West HAC SE with 2 lags, matching the paper.

sampling.notes: Very small control pool (l1nyrec, freightcost, frctotal). Full enumeration trivial.

design_audit.notes: Same time-series framework as G1 but outcome is variance of price difference (constructed squared deviation from group mean). Newey-West with 2 lags.

claim_object.outcome_concept: Variance of cotton price difference (constructed as sample-corrected squared deviation from pre/post period mean)
claim_object.estimand_concept: Effect of telegraph on the variance (dispersion) of the cotton price gap, capturing improved information quality
claim_object.target_population: Daily cotton trade between Liverpool and New York, ~1860-1868

baseline_specs.label: Table2-Col4-variance
baseline_specs.notes: Variance of raw price difference. dev2 = N/(N-1)*(diff - mean(diff|tele))^2.

baseline_specs.label: Table2-Col5-variance-freight
baseline_specs.notes: Variance of price difference net of freight, controlling for lagged NY receipts.
